title: 112_hr198
content: The "Veterans Dog Training Therapy Act" establishes a pilot program within the Department of Veterans Affairs for dog training therapy. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program to assess the effectiveness of using service dogs to address post-deployment mental health and PTSD symptoms for veterans with disabilities. The program will run for five years at three to five VA medical centers, providing training for veterans with mental health conditions. The Secretary will select medical centers for a pilot program to train veterans with mental health conditions in service dog handling. Training areas must be wheelchair accessible and include indoor grooming space, classrooms, offices, equipment storage, outdoor exercise space for dogs, and other training areas. The pilot program for training veterans with mental health conditions in service dog handling will include office space, storage for training equipment, access to other training areas, outdoor exercise space for dogs, and transportation for field trips. The program will be administered through the Recreation Therapy Service of the Department of Veterans Affairs by a certified recreational therapist with administrative experience. The Secretary will administer the pilot program through the Recreation Therapy Service of the Department of Veterans Affairs, overseen by a certified recreational therapist. A director of service dog training will be established for training dogs at selected medical centers, with experience in social services and teaching service dog training. Each pilot program site will have certified service dog training instructors. The pilot program for service dogs in a vocational setting requires experience working with veterans with PTSD, certified instructors, selection of dogs from shelters or foster homes, training in essential commands, and living at the program site or a volunteer foster home during training. The pilot program for service dogs in a vocational setting involves teaching essential commands, living at the program site or a volunteer foster home during training, lecture on training methodologies, hands-on training and grooming, maximizing therapeutic benefits for veterans, and providing well-trained service dogs to veterans with disabilities. The pilot program aims to maximize therapeutic benefits for veterans with disabilities by providing well-trained service dogs. Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder or other mental health conditions can participate if resources are available. Hiring preference for service dog training instructors is given to veterans who have graduated from post-deployment programs. The pilot program aims to provide well-trained service dogs to veterans with disabilities. Hiring preference for service dog training instructors is given to veterans who have graduated from post-deployment programs. The Secretary will collect data to determine the program's effectiveness in reducing stigma, improving emotional regulation, and patience for participating veterans. The program aims to assist veterans by reducing stigma related to mental health conditions, improving emotional regulation, patience, and sense of purpose, providing opportunities to help fellow veterans, reintegrating into the community, building relationship and parenting skills, relaxing hyper-vigilance, improving sleep patterns, and reducing the use of pain medication. The pilot program aims to help veterans by reducing social isolation, building relationship and parenting skills, relaxing hyper-vigilance, improving sleep patterns, and decreasing the use of pain medication. Reports to Congress are required annually to provide information on the number of participants and the effects of the program. The pilot program aims to assist veterans by addressing various issues such as post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms, family dynamics, insomnia, and overall well-being. Congress requires annual reports detailing the number of participants and the program's effects. The curr_chunk discusses the potential benefits of service dogs for veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder, including physiological markers, family dynamics, insomnia, pain management, and overall well-being. It also includes recommendations for extending or expanding the pilot program. The term "service dog training instructor" is defined as someone who trains veterans in service dog handling.
